## 10.5. Lab: Malicious Containers {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__lab_malicious_containers} While containers have made it much easier to deploy software, they have also made it easier to deploy *malicious* software. Imagine that we have an internal company website, written in PHP and deployed in a Docker container. Given the layered nature of the Docker build system, this application is *trusting* that the images it is building from are secure. Take a look at the following `Dockerfile`{.literal} to see just how easy it is to slip something malicious into the image: `shell.php`{.literal} is a shell written in PHP that will execute with the permissions of the web server. This means it will be able to read and write (but not overwrite) in the /var/www/html directory. Let's download, build, and run this image. Download [the malicious.zip file](https://github.com/rxt1077/it230/raw/main/labs/malicious.zip){.link}, unzip it in a directory where you have write access, and navigate to that directory in your shell. ::: callout-list 1. *①* Build the image and tag it `malicious`{.literal}, don't foget the `.`{.literal} at the end! 2. *②* Run the `malicious`{.literal} image and forward local port 8080 to port 80 in the container ::: Now you should be able to navigate to [http://localhost:8080](http://localhost:8080){.link} to see the default web page.
::: content What's for lunch? :::
Now based on the information in the Dockerfile, get a shell on the compromised web server.
::: content Notice of the time off request on the main page doesn't work? From your shell, create a new web page on the server named `timeoff.html`{.literal} with the text `GRANTED`{.literal}. What command did you use to make the new file? What happens now when you click on the time off link? :::
:::::: :::: {.section .sect2 title="10.6. Review Questions"}
topic: Identifying and mitigating security vulnerabilities in Docker containers, including the use of trusted images and secure configuration practices.
question: What command would be used to create a new file named `timeoff.html` with the text `GRANTED` in the `/var/www/html` directory of a Docker container running an Apache web server, assuming the user has the necessary permissions?

choices.A: echo "GRANTED" > /var/www/html/timeoff.html
choices.B: touch /var/www/html/timeoff.html && echo "GRANTED" >> /var/www/html/timeoff.html
choices.C: mkdir /var/www/html/timeoff.html && echo "GRANTED" > /var/www/html/timeoff.html
choices.D: rm /var/www/html/timeoff.html && echo "GRANTED" > /var/www/html/timeoff.html

explanation: The correct answer, A, uses the echo command to create a new file with the specified text. This command is appropriate for the scenario described, as it assumes the user has the necessary permissions to write to the `/var/www/html` directory. The other options are incorrect because they either use unnecessary commands (B), attempt to create a directory instead of a file (C), or delete an existing file before creating a new one (D).

context: ### 7.3.9. Single Sign On (SSO) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__single_sign_on_sso} Given the ubiquitous nature of web applications, maintaining separate usernames and passwords can be difficult for users. A recent trend has been to support Single Sign On, where one identity provider is used to confirm that users are who they claim to be. There are a few protocols that make this possible, including SAML and OAuth. SAML stands for Security Assertion Markup Language and is an XML based Single Sign On solution. The SAML workflow centers around the SAML identity provider or IDP. The following steps take place to grant access to a resource via SAML: ::: {.ordered-list .arabic} 1. [User accesses a sevice]{.principal} 2. [User is redirected to SAML IDP with SAML request]{.principal} 3. [User logs in]{.principal} 4. [Credentials are verified]{.principal} 5. [SAML IDP sends credentials to the service]{.principal} ::: OpenID is another protocol that allows users to authenticated using a third-party identity provider in a similar fashion to SAML. One of the main differences is that OpenID was designed to be decentralized, allowing for multiple IDPs for users to choose from. In February 2014 OpenID introduced OpenID Connect (OIDC), a more modern system that allows IDPs to provide information about users via a REST API. This move was largely in response to the popularity of OAuth. OAuth is a method for allowing websites to access parts of a user's profile with the user's permission. OAuth is not *technically* a full-fledged authentication protocol, but it is often used as part of one. The following diagram highlights the differences between OpenID authentication and an OAuth flow: :::: ::::: {.section .sect3 title="7.3.10. Kerberos"}
topic: The differences between OpenID authentication and an OAuth flow are critical to understanding the nuances of each protocol, and a deep understanding of these differences is essential for implementing effective authentication solutions.
question: What fundamental difference in authentication approach exists between OpenID Connect (OIDC) and OAuth 2.0 that affects how user identities are verified and protected in single sign-on (SSO) implementations?

choices.A: OIDC uses a centralized identity provider, while OAuth 2.0 relies on decentralized authorization servers.
choices.B: OIDC is designed for authentication, providing identity verification, whereas OAuth 2.0 is primarily for authorization, granting access to resources without exposing passwords.
choices.C: OIDC requires a REST API for user information exchange, but OAuth 2.0 uses XML-based assertions.
choices.D: OIDC supports multiple identity providers, but OAuth 2.0 is limited to a single IDP per implementation.

explanation: The correct answer highlights the primary distinction between OIDC and OAuth 2.0, which lies in their design purposes. OIDC is an authentication protocol that verifies the user's identity, while OAuth 2.0 is an authorization framework that grants access to resources on behalf of the user without sharing credentials. This difference is crucial for understanding how each protocol contributes to SSO solutions.

## 5.7. Lab: MitM with Scapy {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__lab_mitm_with_scapy} In this lab we will use a fake SSH server, [sshesame](https://github.com/jaksi/sshesame){.link}, and an interactive packet manipulation program, [scapy](https://scapy.net/){.link}, to disrupt an ongoing SSH session between victim and server, position ourself in the middle of the traffic, and capture the username and password victim is using. :::: table ::: content +-----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | Name | IP Address | +===========================================================+===========================================================+ | server | 172.20.0.5 | +-----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | victim | 172.20.0.6 | +-----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ | attacker | 172.20.0.7 | +-----------------------------------------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------+ : Table 1. IP Addresses Used ::: :::: For this lab our IP addresses are configured statically and are known to the attacker. It is also assumed that the attacker is on the local network. Lastly victim has been poorly configured to ignore changes to the host key. This is not entirely unreasonable as many users just ignore the warnings and clear out the known_hosts file when prompted anyway. Start by downloading the [scapy.zip](https://github.com/rxt1077/it230/raw/main/labs/scapy.zip){.link} file which contains the Docker Compose configuration we will be using. Uncompress it to a directory where you have write access. This lab will require us to use three terminal windows/tabs: one for the `docker-compose up`{.literal} command which will show the output of everything running in the background, one for the victim which will show an SSH session with the server, and one for the attacker which we will use to make the attack. Open three terminals and `cd`{.literal} into the directory where you uncompressed the lab zip file in each of them. There should be a `docker-compose.yml`{.literal} file and `server`{.literal}, `victim`{.literal}, and `attacker`{.literal} directories in the directory you are in. In the first terminal run the `docker-compose up`{.literal} command to build the images and run the containers: ::: callout-list 1. *①* Notice that attacker has a fake SSH server running in the background 2. *②* Notice that server has a legitimate SSH server running in the background :::
::: content If you receive the error `failed to create network scapy_testnet: Error response from daemon: Pool overlaps with other one on this address space`{.literal} check to see if you have other containers running and stop them. You may also need to run `docker network prune`{.literal} to remove the old networks Docker built. :::
In the second terminal run `docker-compose run victim bash`{.literal} and then from the prompt we'll SSH to server using the password \"password\": ::: callout-list 1. *①* The password is \"password\". It will not be echoed to the screen as you type it. :::
::: content If for some reason the password will not work and you are sure you are typing it in correctly you can run the following command `docker compose exec server passwd`{.literal} (note it's *passwd* and not *password*). Type in the password twice and it will be reset to whatever you typed. What you type will not be echoed to the screen. You should now be able to ssh from victim to server with the password you typed in. :::
In the third terminal we'll start by *executing* (recall that at this point it's already running sshesame in the background) a BASH shell on attacker and configuring it to accept packets not only for its own IP address, but also for the server's IP address. Once traffic is routed to us, this will allow attacker to also respond to packets destined for 172.20.0.5. ::: callout-list 1. *①* This is the IP we started with 2. *②* This is an additional IP that attacker believes it has ::: Now that the attacker system is configured, we'll start up `scapy`{.literal} interactively: You'll notice that scapy's prompt is \>\>\>, just like python because it *is* python. Since we're working in python, let's make our lives easier by defining a few simple variables: ::: callout-list 1. *①* IPv4 addresses are strings in scapy ::: Now let's see how scapy allows us to build packets. We'll make an Ethernet frame, with an IP packet inside it, with an ICMP echo request in that, with the data being set to our name: ::: callout-list 1. *①* Scapy uses the \'/\' operator to nest protocols. This is my name in an ICMP packet, in an IP packet, in an Ethernet frame. Be sure you use your own name! 2. *②* The `show()`{.literal} command prints out packets in detail 3. *③* The `srp1()`{.literal} function sends and receives *one* packet at Layer 2 ::: Notice how we use this to capture the server's MAC address and save it in the `server_mac`{.literal} variable.
::: content Take a screenshot of your scapy session at this point showing that you completed an ICMP echo request/response with your name in it. :::
We can also determine MAC addresses at Layer 2 with an ARP \"who-has\" request. Let's craft and send a broadcast ethernet frame with an ARP \"who-has\" request for the victims's IP address. The result will tell use what the victim's MAC address is: ::: callout-list 1. *①* This is my MAC address of victim, but yours may be different! ::: This is how an ARP exchange is supposed to work. We broadcast out asking what MAC we should use for a certain IP and we get a response *from the person who legitimately has that MAC and IP*. We have everything we need to create an ARP packet telling the victim to send traffic to us when they are trying to access servers IP: Now let's make and view an evil ARP packet: This packet posits itself as coming from the server, it is aimed at the victim in both IP and MAC, but the MAC address that will be used to send it is ours (by default, we don't specify with `hwsrc`{.literal}). This means the victim will update their ARP cache such that frames destined for server go to attacker. This effectively reroutes all layer 2 traffic that was going to the server from the victim. Go ahead an send that ARP packet: Now go back to the victim terminal with the SSH connection to server and try typing something. As soon as SSH has to send data, you will get a broken pipe error and the connection will drop. Faced with such a problem, what do you think most users will do? Probably try to reconnect, let's try that too. Remember the password is \"password\". ::: callout-list 1. *①* This happened when they tried to type something right after we sent the malicious ARP ::: Wait, that prompt looks a little different and where's the message about staying logged in? It turns out the victim actually signed into our fake SSH server and their username and password were logged! Take a look at the output from the terminal running `docker-compose up`{.literal}, you'll see the credentials entered:
:::: content ::: description-list [How would you create an ARP packet in scapy to reverse the change you made previously and fix the route?]{.term} : []{.principal} [Would using keys instead of passwords help prevent this kind of attack? Why or why not?]{.term} : []{.principal} [How would [managing host keys correctly](https://www.ssh.com/academy/ssh/host-key){.link} prevent this kind of attack?]{.term} : []{.principal} ::: ::::
To stop the running containers, you can type Ctrl-C in the terminal running `docker-compose up`{.literal}, exit out of the victim, and exit out of the attacker. ::::::::::::::::: :::: {.section .sect2 title="5.8. Review Questions"}
topic: Understanding the concept and implications of a Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attack.
question: What is the primary vulnerability exploited in the MitM attack described in the lab exercise, and how can it be mitigated?

choices.A: Weak password authentication
choices.B: Poor host key management
choices.C: Unencrypted SSH traffic

context: # 1. Introduction {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__introduction} ::: {.section .sect2 title="1.1. Managing Risk"} ## 1.1. Managing Risk {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__managing_risk} *Information security* (infosec) is largely the practice of preventing *unauthorized access* to data. Unauthorized access is when an actor gains access to data that they do not have the permissions to access. The system is often used in an unintended manner to provide such access. Data has become an increasingly valuable asset and the *risks* of others having access to data are incredibly high. Because of this, information security typically falls under the risk-management plan of a company and its importance cannot be understated. This is evidenced by the fact that information technology's (IT) typical role in a company has migrated from a basic service provider to directorships with a seat at the highest decision making table. This is directly due to the fact that IT assets have become the most valuable things many companies own. Guarding these assets and managing the inherent risk of their loss is the job of information security professionals. *Malicious software*, also referred to as malware, is often employed to help an attacker gain access to a system. Many types of malicious software exist, but the common thread is that they perform actions that cause harm to a computer system or network. In the case of many attacks, *system failure* may occur either as an intended (as is the case in Denial of Service (DoS) attacks) or unintended consequence. This means the system will no longer be able to perform its intended purpose. System failure is a serious risk that needs to be managed. ::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.2. Learning the Lingo"}
topic: The intersection of information security with other aspects of business operations, including its role in supporting business objectives and ensuring the continuity of critical systems and services.
question: What is the primary consequence of a Denial of Service (DoS) attack on a computer system or network, and how does it relate to the overall risk management strategy in information security?

choices.A: Data breach and financial loss
choices.B: System failure and disruption of critical services
choices.C: Malware infection and data corruption
choices.D: Unauthorized access and privilege escalation

explanation: A Denial of Service (DoS) attack is intended to cause system failure, making the system unable to perform its intended purpose. This consequence is directly related to the overall risk management strategy in information security, as it highlights the importance of managing the risk of system failure and ensuring the continuity of critical systems and services.

# 10. Virtualization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__virtualization}
Information Technology has seen massive growth in the adoption of virtualization as the underpinning of dynamic and

robust systems. This shift from bare-metal resources to virtual resources provides its own unique security challenges

and considerations. As the field changes, it is important for anyone working in cybersecurity to not only understand how

these systems work, but also be able to approach their implementation with a security-first mindset.

### 4.4.5. RDP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__rdp}
Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) is build into Windows and is typically used to control a machine remotely. It works over

port 3389 via TCP or UDP. While RDP can be quite useful for performing remote administration on a remote machine, it can

also be a large security hole if a bad actor gains access. RDP use in ransomware attacks is on the rise as ransomware

programs may use RDP to find other machines to attack.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.6. Telnet"}


### 4.4.6. Telnet {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__telnet}
Telnet is an antiquated remote administration tool that gives access to a shell via a cleartext channel. Telnet runs on

port 23 and while still occasionally in use it should largely be phased out. You will still find telnet in embedded

applications and legacy systems. You may also see the client being used to inspect other types of traffic. For example,

you can use a telnet client to submit HTTP requests or send email via SMTP.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.7. SSH"}
topic: The role of Telnet in legacy systems and embedded applications, and the potential security risks associated with its continued use in these contexts.
question: What significant security vulnerability is inherent in Telnet's operation that makes its continued use in legacy systems and embedded applications particularly risky?

choices.A: It uses a proprietary encryption method.
choices.B: It operates over a cleartext channel.
choices.C: It requires frequent password changes.
choices.D: It is limited to local network access only.

explanation: Telnet's operation over a cleartext channel means that all data exchanged during a Telnet session, including passwords, is transmitted in plaintext, making it easily interceptable and readable by unauthorized parties. This poses a significant security risk, especially in applications where security is paramount.

topic: The challenges and opportunities of implementing access controls in cloud-based security solutions, including potential trade-offs between security and convenience.
question: What is a critical consideration for cloud-based access control systems that must balance the need for robust security with the demand for user convenience, and how might this balance impact the implementation of identification, authentication, authorization, and accounting processes?

choices.A: Ensuring scalability without compromising privacy
choices.B: Implementing multi-factor authentication to reduce phishing risks
choices.C: Prioritizing ease of access over data encryption to enhance user experience
choices.D: Integrating artificial intelligence to predict and prevent unauthorized access attempts

These systems must be able to scale to meet the demands of a potentially large and distributed user base without compromising the privacy and security of the data they protect. This requires careful planning and implementation to ensure that security measures are robust yet do not unduly inconvenience users, affecting their productivity and adoption of the system.

topic: Best practices for backup storage and retrieval to ensure data integrity and availability in the event of a security incident.

context: #### Counter (CTR) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__counter_ctr} ::: float-group Instead of using an IV, CTR uses a nonce (random number that is the same for all blocks) and counter. The counter is incremented with each block, meaning this mode can function in parallel. CTR mode solves the problems of ECB while still providing an algorithm that can run quickly on modern machines. ::: :::: ::::: {.section .sect4 title="Galois/Counter Mode (GCM)"} #### Galois/Counter Mode (GCM) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__galoiscounter_mode_gcm} ::: float-group GCM uses a counter like CTR, but does not make use of a nonce. Instead an IV is used with the inititial counter. GCM also generates a message authentication code (MAC) for each block to verify the integrity of the block. This combination makes for a modern, robust algorithm that is gaining rapid adoption. :::
topic: The advantages of using Counter (CTR) mode in encryption, including its ability to function in parallel and solve the problems associated with ECB mode.
question: What critical advantage does the Counter (CTR) mode offer over other encryption modes like ECB, in terms of operational efficiency, and how does it leverage its counter mechanism to achieve this?

choices.A: It provides sequential encryption, relying on the previous block's ciphertext to encrypt the next.
choices.B: It enables parallel processing of blocks, utilizing a counter to maintain consistency across the encrypted data.
choices.C: It incorporates a feedback mechanism to enhance security against certain types of attacks.
choices.D: It uses a fixed initialization vector for all encryption operations, simplifying key management.

explanation: CTR mode's use of a counter allows for the parallel encryption of blocks, as each block can be encrypted independently using the counter value. This is a significant advantage over modes like ECB, which do not provide such efficiency benefits due to their sequential nature or other limitations.

### 5.5.8. Directory Traversal {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__directory_traversal}
A poorly designed web server may be subject to a directory traversal attack. Recall that web servers are designed to

serve static content from a particular directory, `/var/www`{.literal} for example. Now suppose that an attacker

submitted a `GET`{.literal} request for

[`http://www.example.com/../../etc/shadow`{.literal}](http://www.example.com/../../etc/shadow){.link}. It is possible

that the web server may actually go up two directories and serve that file.

This can be addressed with file permissions, access controls, and filtering incoming requests. It is important to note

that there is more than one way to specify a path in an HTTP request, including using URL encoding, so all possible

malicious inputs must be sanitized.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.9. URL Hijacking/Typosquating"}


### 5.5.9. URL Hijacking/Typosquating {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__url_hijackingtyposquating}
An unfortunately common, broad-based attack is to buy a domain with a similar name to a very popular domain. When users

mistype the popular domain they end up at the malicious actor's website. For example, imagine if someone registered

`gooogle.com`{.literal} (note the three o's). They could gain a lot of traffic from people who mistyped google.

These sites could be used for ad revenue, phishing credentials, or even possibly to distribute malware. A mitigation

that several browsers implement is to keep a list of malicious websites and warn users before they visit them.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.10. Domain Hijacking"}
topic: The importance of sanitizing all possible malicious inputs, including those using URL encoding, is a key aspect of preventing directory traversal attacks, and a professional domain expert should be able to explain this concept in detail.
question: What critical security measure must be taken to prevent a web server from serving sensitive files when an attacker submits a GET request with a URL-encoded path?

choices.A: Implementing strict file permissions
choices.B: Sanitizing all possible malicious inputs, including URL encoding
choices.C: Using secure communication protocols like HTTPS
choices.D: Regularly updating the web server software

explanation: The correct answer, sanitizing all possible malicious inputs, including URL encoding, is crucial because directory traversal attacks often exploit the server's ability to interpret URL-encoded paths. By sanitizing these inputs, a web server can prevent attackers from accessing sensitive files outside the intended directory.

context: ### 3.3.4. Cryptojacking {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__cryptojacking} Crypto currencies utilizing proof-of-work algorithms have made it easier than ever for programs to convert processor cycles into money. Certain types of malware capitalize on this by mining cryptocurrency in the background on a users machine. This theft of power and resources can result income for the malware distributor when the funds from mining are deposited into their online wallet. Cryptojacking is more popular than ever, especially considering that large botnets of infected machines have already been created. Cryptojacking creates a simpler path to monetization for malicious actors who may already have control of many compromised machines. ::: :::::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.5. Rootkit"} ### 3.3.5. Rootkit {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__rootkit} :::: float-group A rootkit is a secret program designed to give back door access to a system. They are designed to remain hidden and may even actively disable or circumvent security software. Due to their low-level nature, many rootkits can be difficult to detect and even more difficult to remove. Rootkits are often classified in accordance with the layer in which they are hidden: ::: description-list [Firmware Rootkit]{.term} : [Firmware is code that a hardware device uses to run. It is often a thin layer of commands used for setting up and interfacing with the device. A firmware rootkit may reside in the BIOS of a motherboard and can be very difficult to remove.]{.principal} [Bootloader Rootkit]{.term} : [A bootloader prepares the system to boot an operating system kernel, typically by loading the kernel into memory. A bootloader rootkit may hijack this process to load itself into separate memory space or manipulate the kernel being loaded.]{.principal} [Kernel-mode Rootkit]{.term} : [Many operating system kernel, including Linux, have the ability to load dynamic modules. These kernel modules have complete access to OS kernel operations. A kernel-mode rootkit can be difficult to detect live as the OS kernel being given the instructions to detect the rootkit can no longer be trusted.]{.principal} [Application Rootkit]{.term} : [An application or user-mode rootkit is usually installed as an application that runs in the background with administrative privileges. These rootkits are typically the easiest to develop and deploy, a low-level knowledge of the hardware the system is using is not required, but they are also the easiest to detect and remove.]{.principal} ::: ::::
topic: Discuss the significance of Rootkits in the context of computer system security, including their potential impact on system integrity and the challenges they pose for security software and protocols.
question: What is the primary challenge in detecting and removing Kernel-mode Rootkits, and how does this impact the overall security of a computer system?

choices.A: The primary challenge is that Kernel-mode Rootkits can manipulate the OS kernel, making it difficult to trust the kernel's instructions.
choices.B: The primary challenge is that Kernel-mode Rootkits require administrative privileges to install.
choices.C: The primary challenge is that Kernel-mode Rootkits are typically installed as applications that run in the background.
choices.D: The primary challenge is that Kernel-mode Rootkits can only be detected through manual analysis of system logs.

explanation: The correct answer, A, highlights the primary challenge in detecting and removing Kernel-mode Rootkits, which is that they can manipulate the OS kernel, making it difficult to trust the kernel's instructions. This requires a deep understanding of how Kernel-mode Rootkits operate and the implications they have on computer system security.

### 3.3.7. RAT {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__rat}
RAT stands for Remote Access Trojan an it is used to gain full access and control of a remote target. The malware

distributor can browse the files on a computer, send keystrokes and mouse movements, view the screen, and/or monitor the

input from the microphone and camera. RATs often actively bypass security controls and as such they may be difficult to

detect.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.8. Adware / Potentially Unwanted Programs (PUP)"}


### 3.3.8. Adware / Potentially Unwanted Programs (PUP) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__adware_potentially_unwanted_programs_pup}
Adware is malware that is designed to track user behavior and deliver unwanted, sometimes intrusive, tailored ads.

Adware may slow down a system and/or add ad walls to sites. This type of malware often targets a users web browser.

Potentially Unwanted Programs (PUP) are typically downloaded as part of the install of another program. Commons PUPs are

browser toolbars, PDF readers, compression utilities, or browser extensions. These programs may have adware/spyware

components in them and can also slow down a system.

:::

## Zero Days
::: content

Modern operating systems employ layers of security to ensure that programs do not have access to sensitive information

or applications. This typically means that for malware to be effective, it needs to elevate its privileges. The most

effective malware can perform privilege escalation without requiring user interaction. To do this malware may rely on

new/undocumented exploits or vulnerabilities. These new exploits that have been disclosed for \"zero days\" are hence

are referred to as *zero days*. Zero days are incredibly powerful and may be hoarded by APTs/criminal groups or sold for

millions of dollars on the Dark Web.

:::

</aside>

## 3.3. Types of Malware {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__types_of_malware}
The definition of malware is so broad and new malware is being created daily. This can make it difficult to classify

malware. As we go through some basic types, please keep in mind that there is significant overlap. For example, you may

encounter ransomware distributed as a virus *or* ransomware distributed as a trojan. The fact that it is ransomware does

not preclude it from being some other type of malware as well.

:::::::::::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.1. Worms, Viruses, and Trojans"}
topic: The significance of understanding operating system security layers in preventing or mitigating malware attacks, including those utilizing zero days.
question: What primary mechanism do zero-day exploits typically target to achieve their goals in the context of operating system security?

choices.A: Network Firewalls
choices.B: User Authentication Protocols
choices.C: Privilege Escalation Mechanisms
choices.D: Data Encryption Algorithms

explanation: Zero-day exploits are incredibly powerful tools used by malware to bypass security measures. They often rely on exploiting previously unknown vulnerabilities in software. In the context of operating system security, the primary goal of such exploits is to gain elevated privileges, allowing the malware to perform actions that would otherwise be restricted. This is why privilege escalation mechanisms are the primary target for zero-day exploits, as they enable malware to move from a limited user context to a more powerful, potentially system-administrative context.

context: ### 3.3.2. Ransomware {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ransomware} Ransomware is a type of malware that encrypts files and demands a ransom to decrypt them. Modern ransomware uses symmetric encryption to the files quickly and then encrypts the symmetric key asymmetrically using a hard-coded public key for which the threat actor has the corresponding private key. When the ransom is paid, typically via cryptocurrency, the threat actor can decrypt the symmetric key using their private key and the user can use the symmetric key to decrypt the files. Ransomware is considered a data breach in the data is often exfiltrated as well. It is also worth noting that when the ransom is paid, there is no guarantee that the threat actor will actually begin the decryption process. Typical targets of ransomware include corporate infrastructure and health care systems although ransomware may also be spread indeterminately. The payout of ransoms can be a large money-making enterprise so many APTs or criminal groups may employ its use. Ransomware is considered the biggest threat to cyber stability today. ::: :::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.3. Spyware"}

choices.D: Hash function

context: ## 6.7. Email Solutions {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__email_solutions} The original protocols used to send/receive email were simple and not designed for the challenges we face today. SPAM and phishing emails are unfortunately common and can be addressed with email client add-ons that scan for viruses or use patterns to identify phishing emails. Many of these tools are already built into Google's GMail or Microsofts Exchange. Another large challenge is verifying the sender of an email. Currently three common methods exist: Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM), and Domain-base Message Authentication, Reporting, and Conformance (DMARC). SPF utilizes TXT records on a DNS domain to verify the IP of a sender. When inbound mail is received, the SPF information for the domain of the sender is retrieved, giving an allowed list of IPs. For example, NJIT's SPF record currently looks like this: It is important to note that not all of these IPs belong to NJIT. Some may be groups that send emails on NJIT's behalf like mass mailers, web applications, etc. When properly configured SPF prevents an attacker from impersonating emails from a domain. DKIM utilizes public and private key cryptography to ensure that an email originated from a particular SMTP server. Public keys for a domain are advertised through a TXT DNS record for a particular domain. Private keys are used by the SMTP server for that domain to sign the emails being sent. A receiving SMTP server can then verify that the message originated from a valid SMTP server for that domain. Private keys can also be distributed to SMTP servers that send emails on behalf of the domain. DMARC applies policies to the SPF and DKIM validations. DMARC answers questions like, \"What should I do if a message is from a valid SPF IP but doesn't have a valid DKIM signature?\" or \"What should I do with a message that looks like SPAM but has a valid DKIM signature?\" DMARC puts many of the tools used to verify email together in a layered approach to determine whether to pass, quarantine, or block an email. ::: :::: {.section .sect2 title="6.8. SIEM"}
topic: The best practices for implementing and managing email verification methods in an organization.
question: What is the primary difference between how DKIM and SPF verify the authenticity of an email, and how does DMARC utilize the results of these verifications to determine the appropriate action for an incoming email?

choices.A: DKIM verifies the sender's SMTP server using public-key cryptography, while SPF checks the sender's IP against a list of approved IPs, and DMARC uses the results to block or quarantine emails based on predefined policies.
choices.B: DKIM checks the email content for spam patterns, SPF verifies the sender's domain, and DMARC applies machine learning algorithms to predict email legitimacy.
choices.C: SPF uses public-key cryptography to sign emails, DKIM checks the sender's IP, and DMARC applies policies based on the sender's reputation.
choices.D: DKIM and SPF are both used for encrypting email content, and DMARC is used for decrypting emails from trusted senders.

explanation: The correct answer requires an understanding of how DKIM and SPF work, including DKIM's use of public and private key cryptography to verify the SMTP server and SPF's use of DNS records to verify the sender's IP. It also requires knowledge of how DMARC applies policies to the results of these verifications to determine whether to pass, quarantine, or block an email.

## Sony Rootkit
::: content

In 2005 Sony released CDs for their music software with an application rootkit designed to run on Microsoft Windows

systems. The rootkit ran persistently in the background, slowing systems, and did not have an uninstaller to remove the

program. It was designed to prevent the OS from copying information from audio CDs, but it also opened up several

security holes that could be exploited by other malware. Ultimately the rootkit led to several class-action lawsuits

against Sony BMG and a led to a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission that required Sony to reimburse customers

who reported damages from the rootkit.

:::

### 3.3.6. Botnet {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__botnet}
A botnet is a network of exploited hosts controlled by a single party. These hosts may be desktop computers, servers, or

even internet of things (IoT) devices. Botnets are often used in large-scale distributed denial of service (DDoS)

attacks where the nature of the attack is to have many machines flooding a single machine with traffic. Botnets may also

be used to send spam emails as their access to SMTP email relay may vary depending on their internet service provider

(ISP).

Bots are typically controlled through a command and control (C2, C&C) server. While this C2 server may use a custom

protocol, it is far more typical for modern botnets to rely on other infrastructure. C2 traffic can use SSH, HTTP,

Internet Relay Chat (IRC), or even Discord to send commands to bots and receive data from bots.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.3.7. RAT"}

choices.D: SMTP

explanation: SSH (Secure Shell) is a protocol that provides secure access to remote computers and is known for its end-to-end encryption. This encryption capability makes SSH a protocol that can potentially complicate the detection and interception of C2 traffic by security measures.

context: ### 6.3.2. Proxy {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__proxy} A proxy typically sits between the users and an external network. Proxies and receive and send requests on behalf of a user, allowing for full control over the traffic going out and coming back in. Proxies can be used for caching, access control, URL filtering, content scanning, and even packet inspection. Proxy solutions may be explicit or transparent and are offered by many companies including McAfee, Fortigate, Netsparker, and Palo Alto. A typical application of a proxy would be to filter explicit content on a school district network. Proxies can also be broken into *forward* and *reverse* configurations. A forward proxy passes requests from a private or internal network to the internet. Forward proxies can speed up local requests through caching and validate that the request should be performed. Forward proxies are interoperable with standard firewalls and network address translation (NAT). Reverse proxies take requests from an external source and pass it to an internal service. This helps prevent clients from having direct access to internal services. Reverse proxies can utilize caching and validate requests as well. A reverse proxy can also be configured to work with a firewall. Whereas it used to be common practice to place a server in a demilitarized zone (DMZ) outside of a firewall, it is now far more common to employ a reverse proxy to reach that server. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.3. Load Balancer"}
topic: The use of proxies in improving network security, including their ability to validate requests, prevent direct access to internal services, and utilize caching to speed up local requests.
question: What primary security benefit does a reverse proxy offer when deployed in front of an internal service, and how does this enhance the overall security posture of the network?

choices.A: It accelerates internet traffic through caching, thereby improving network performance.
choices.B: It conceals the internal service's IP address, preventing direct client access and reducing the attack surface.
choices.C: It filters out malicious packets based on predefined rules, acting as an intrusion prevention system.
choices.D: It distributes incoming traffic across multiple servers, ensuring no single point of failure.

explanation: A reverse proxy enhances network security by preventing clients from having direct access to internal services. This is achieved by the reverse proxy acting as an intermediary, receiving requests from external sources and forwarding them to the internal service. This configuration helps protect the internal service from direct attacks and reduces the risk of exposure.

## 9.5. MITRE ATT&CK Framework {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__mitre_attck_framework}
In the [Malware](#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__malware){.xref} chapter we covered Lockheed

adversarial tactics, techniques, and common knowledge. Each section is separated into different matrices that have their

Reconnaissance is the act of collecting information about a target. This typically involves vulnerability scanning,

network mapping, and phishing. Attackers are generally looking for weak links and a way in to the company. Understanding

how reconnaissance is performed can help a security team pick up on the precursors to an incident.

:::

### 7.3.11. Tokenization {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__tokenization} Tokenization may be used as part of an access control scheme to protect sensitive information. Information that would be highly valuable if compromised is replaced with a random token known to the parties involved in the transaction. In a typically scenario once the tokens have been established, only the token is sent out over an untrusted network. Imagine you don't want your credit card number exposed to merchants. One solution would be if you used a payment service that issued you a new credit card number for each transaction. This credit card number would only be valid for a single transaction and would be billed to your regular credit card (which the payment service would have access to). In this case the token is the one-time-use credit card number and the sensitive information is your actual credit card number. Payment services like ApplePay and GoogleWallet do exactly this. ::: ::::::::::::::::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="7.4. Lab: Linux File Permissions"} ## 7.4. Lab: Linux File Permissions {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__lab_linux_file_permissions} In this lab we are going to explore UNIX style file permissions and determine what they can do and why they are limited. Finally we will see how Linux ACLs provide more flexibility in assigning permissions. We will be working in a vanilla Ubuntu container and installing software and adding users manually. Let's start up the container, install the packages we need, and add some users to work with: Traditional UNIX file permissions support user and group ownership of a file. Read, write, and execute permissions for a file can be set for the user, group, or others. You can view the permissions of a file with the `ls -l`{.literal} command. Let's make home directories for Alice, Bob, and Carol and view the default permissions: The text `drwxr-xr-x`{.literal} tells us that these files are directories, the owner has read/write/execute permission, the group has read/execute permission, and other users have read/execute permission. It is important to note that execute permissions are required for viewing the contents of a directory. Files owners and a groups are set with the `chown`{.literal} command, following the format `chown . `{.literal}. Let's try to use this command to make the home directories of alice, bob, and carol private: When a user is added to a UNIX system with the `useradd`{.literal} command a group with their name is created. This allows us to pass a group to `chown`{.literal} that only they will have access to. While this is a good start, others still have the ability to read and execute these directories, meaning *anyone* can view the contents. To prove this, lets assume the role of dave and try doing an `ls`{.literal} on each of the directories: ::: callout-list 1. *①* `su`{.literal} allows us to assume the role of anyone, often it is used to assume the role of the *superuser* ::: The `ls`{.literal} command was successful even though there were no files to look at. If we weren't able to view the contents, we would have received a permission denied error. The `chmod`{.literal} command is used to modify file permissions for a User (`u`{.literal}), Group (`g`{.literal}), Others (`o`{.literal}), or All (`a`{.literal}). `chmod`{.literal} can remove a permission with `-`{.literal}, add a permission with `+`{.literal}, or set a permission (removing others) with `=`{.literal}. Let's use `chmod`{.literal} to actually make these home directories private: Things look much better, but let's test it and see if Dave can view any of the directories: Lastly, lets make sure that Alice can view the contents of her home directory: Looks good!
::: content Using your first name (all lowercase) add yourself as a user and create a home directory for yourself. Set the permissions such that only you can view the contents. Show the permissions of the home directory and demonstrate that another user *cannot* view its contents. Take a screenshot showing all of this and submit this as one of your deliverables. :::
Unfortunately traditional UNIX file permissions often do not provide the granularity needed in a modern system. For example, lets assume that we wanted a web server to be able to view the contents of Alice, Bob, and Carol's home directories. This is typically done to allow users to place a `public_html`{.literal} directory in their home directory and set up a personal web space. We could do this by making their home directories viewable by others, but then we have the same issue we started with. We could also do this by changing the group ownership of their home directories to a group that the web server is part of, but then we open up the home directories to any other users or services that are part of that group. The solution to this problem is to use Linux ACLs, which allow you to fine tune permissions. Two commands, `setfacl`{.literal} and `getfacl`{.literal} are used to adjust Linux ACLs. Physical Access {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__physical_access} ::: float-group An organization's building is a large ongoing investment and is often an unexpected security asset or weakness. Most technical security controls can be completely bypassed or disabled if physical security is not taken into account. As such, steps must be taken to assure that physical access is limited to protect not only the building and its contents but also the data that is created and stored there. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="7.2.1. Gates"} ### 7.2.1. Gates {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__gates} It is easier to manage the physical security of a location when the amount of entry points are limited. Convenience and safety dictate that even with such considerations multiple points of ingress are still needed. A security gate is the most basic tool available the ensure that only authorized actors gain access. Security gates can be manned or unmanned and designed to support vehicular or pedestrian traffic. In general an unmanned security gate is not going to be as effective as a manned security gate. Likewise, vehicular gates will be less effective against foot traffic (especially unmanned vehicular gates) than gates or checkpoints designed for individuals. A thorough risk assessment is often the first step in planning where to put gates and what types of gates to use. ::: :::: {.section .sect3 title="7.2.2. Biometrics"}

### 4.4.10. DNSSEC {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__dnssec}
Domain Name System Security Extensions (DNSSEC) is a suite of extension specifications designed to authenticate

responses to domain name lookups. This can help prevent MitM attacks by checking the digital signature of the responding

server. While this is certainly helpful, it is important to note that DNSSEC does not provide confidentiality. DNS

resolutions can still be monitored by anyone who has access to the traffic.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="4.4.11. IMAP/POP3"}


### 4.4.11. IMAP/POP3 {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__imappop3}
Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) and Post Office Protocol 3 (POP3) are two protocols used to retrieve email from

a server. IMAP is the more recent protocol which supports saving mail on the sever and folders. POP3 is more primitive,

supporting only the retrieval (and subsequent deletion from the server) of emails. Both protocols use cleartext and are

now commonly run over TLS. POP3 defaults to TCP port 110 or 995 if using TLS. IMAP defaults to TCP port 143 or 993 if

using TLS. In the age of webmail it is easy to forget about these protocols, but a security specialist must keep them in

mind as they may still be used in support of corporate devices.

:::

SNMP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__snmp} ::: float-group Simple Network Management Protocol is used for gathering information about the workings of a network. It is broken into two groups: clients using UDP port 161 (TLS 10161) and a manager using UDP port 162 (TLS 10162). SNMP can be used to pass information about the temperature of a machine, how many connections it currently has, the channel capacity currently being utilized, etc. SNMP is currently up to version 3 which is encrypted and requires authentication. ### 9.5.8. Credential Access {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__credential_access}
With malware running on at least one machine, an attacker may attempt to steal credentials. This could involve logging

key strokes, performing MitM attacks n the local network, brute force programs, cracking locally stored hashes, or

exploiting password managers. Credentials give an attacker a means to log in to other machines on the network and expand

their assets.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.5.9. Discovery"}


### 9.5.9. Discovery {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__discovery}
A malicious actor will try to collect as much information as possible about the environment in which they are operating.

Knowing about available accounts, types of network traffic, running services, stored passwords, and security

countermeasures help them make informed decisions regarding next steps. Internal policies can also be helpful, it's much

easier to guess passwords when you know the company password policy. Expect that at some point after initial access, an

attacker will try to gain more information.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="9.5.10. Lateral Movement"}
topic: Analyzing the role of credential access in expanding an attacker's control within a network and evaluating strategies for prevention.
question: What is the primary mechanism by which stolen credentials enable lateral movement in a network, and how can implementing a robust password policy, including multi-factor authentication, mitigate this risk?

choices.A: By exploiting weak passwords and lack of multi-factor authentication, allowing attackers to move undetected.
choices.B: Through the use of VPNs, which can be compromised with stolen credentials, giving access to the entire network.
choices.C: By directly accessing network devices and configuring them for unauthorized access, which can be prevented by regular firmware updates.
choices.D: By using stolen credentials to phishing other users, creating a cascade effect of compromised accounts, which can be stopped by employee education.

explanation: Stolen credentials, particularly when combined with weak password policies and the absence of multi-factor authentication, provide attackers with the means to log in to other machines on the network, thereby expanding their control. Implementing robust password policies, including multi-factor authentication, significantly raises the bar for attackers, making it much harder for them to use stolen credentials for lateral movement.

context: # 1. Introduction {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__introduction} ::: {.section .sect2 title="1.1. Managing Risk"} ## 1.1. Managing Risk {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__managing_risk} *Information security* (infosec) is largely the practice of preventing *unauthorized access* to data. Unauthorized access is when an actor gains access to data that they do not have the permissions to access. The system is often used in an unintended manner to provide such access. Data has become an increasingly valuable asset and the *risks* of others having access to data are incredibly high. Because of this, information security typically falls under the risk-management plan of a company and its importance cannot be understated. This is evidenced by the fact that information technology's (IT) typical role in a company has migrated from a basic service provider to directorships with a seat at the highest decision making table. This is directly due to the fact that IT assets have become the most valuable things many companies own. Guarding these assets and managing the inherent risk of their loss is the job of information security professionals. *Malicious software*, also referred to as malware, is often employed to help an attacker gain access to a system. Many types of malicious software exist, but the common thread is that they perform actions that cause harm to a computer system or network. In the case of many attacks, *system failure* may occur either as an intended (as is the case in Denial of Service (DoS) attacks) or unintended consequence. This means the system will no longer be able to perform its intended purpose. System failure is a serious risk that needs to be managed. ::: ::::::: {.section .sect2 title="1.2. Learning the Lingo"}
topic: The role of information security in preventing unauthorized access to valuable data assets and its integration into a company's risk-management plan.

choices.A: Data Breach
choices.B: System Failure
choices.C: Malware Infection
choices.D: Unauthorized Access

explanation: A Denial of Service (DoS) attack is intended to cause system failure, making the system unable to perform its intended purpose. This is a critical consequence that needs to be managed as part of a company's risk-management plan.

### 6.3.3. Load Balancer {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__load_balancer}
A common application for reverse proxies is to act as a load balancer for traffic. Load balancers distribute work, in

the form of external client requests, among the internal resources, typically servers.

For example, if a company has four servers supporting a web application, they may employ a reverse proxy load balancer

that takes requests from clients and passes that request to one of the four internal servers. Different metrics are used

to determine how the servers are utilized including least used (round robin), weighted, least amount of active

connections. Load balancers optimize bandwidth and increase availability.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.4. VPN"}


### 6.3.4. VPN {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__vpn}
A virtual private network (VPN) is used to encrypt internet traffic between two networks or a client and a network. VPNs

have become standard procedure for linking remote offices or connecting remote workers. Given the growth of working from

home, almost all users have become familiar with what a VPN is and what it does.

Site-to-site VPNs are typically used for linking offices together. This kind of VPN is on permanently. An example would

be linking two college campuses: NJIT Newark and NJIT Jersey City. In this scenario users on either campus expect to be

able to connect securely to services on the opposite campus at all times. The traffic is encrypted and carried over the

Internet.

Remote access VPNs are used by individuals connecting in to a secure network. This kind of VPN is usually stated through

a application such as Cisco AnyConnect. When the application is running the user is able to securely access internal

resources as if they were at the office.

Many vendors offer VPN products including Cisco, Citrix, Fortinet, Palo Alto, and Checkpoint. Many open source options

also exist for building VPNs including [OpenVPN](https://openvpn.net/){.link},

[WireGuard](https://www.wireguard.com/){.link}, and

[IPsec](https://linuxhint.com/how-to-implement-ipsec-in-linux/){.link}.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.5. TAP"}

## 4.2. Internet Layer Protocols {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__internet_layer_protocols}
:::: {.section .sect3 title="4.2.1. IP"}


### 4.2.1. IP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ip}
IP stands for internet protocol and it was devised to allow creating a network of networks. The network of networks that

uses it primarily is the Internet, although you could use IP in other scenarios as well. IP is largely concerned with

*routing* traffic across and to networks. The protocol was first detailed by the IEEE in 1974 and comes from the

Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) project, which created the first large, packet-switched network.

Most people are familiar with IP addresses, the unique number given to a host participating in an IP network. Currently

there are two main versions of the IP protocol, IPv4 and IPv6, and one of the major differences is in how many IP

addresses are available. IPv4 supports 32 bit addresses and IPv6 supports 128 bit addresses. To give an idea of how big

of a change that is, we have currently allocated all possible IPv4 addresses, but with IPv6 we could give an address to

every grain of sand on the beaches of earth and still not run out.

<aside class="sidebar titled" title="IPv6 Security Implications" epub:type="sidebar">
topic: The relationship between IP and other Internet Layer Protocols, including their interactions and interdependencies.
question: What critical advantage does IPv6 offer over IPv4 in terms of network address allocation, and what potential impact could this have on future network scalability?

choices.A: IPv6 offers a 16-bit address space, potentially impacting network scalability by limiting future expansions.
choices.B: IPv6 offers a 128-bit address space, potentially impacting network scalability by allowing for virtually unlimited device connections.
choices.C: IPv6 offers a 64-bit address space, potentially impacting network scalability by necessitating more frequent address reallocations.
choices.D: IPv6 offers no significant advantage in terms of network address allocation compared to IPv4.

explanation: IPv6's 128-bit address space is a critical advantage over IPv4's 32-bit address space, allowing for a vastly greater number of unique addresses. This difference has significant implications for network scalability, as it enables the connection of a virtually unlimited number of devices without the need for address reallocation or conservation techniques.

### 10.1.2. Containers {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__containers}
A container simplifies the VM by using the same operating system kernel as the host. This is accomplished by using

special features of the Linux kernel to isolate the container. [Linux

namespaces](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/namespaces.7.html){.link} controlled by

[cgroups](https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/cgroups.7.html){.link} allow a daemon (Docker, podman, etc.) to make an

environment where the application has limited access to the full system. Typically containers are used to run a single

application as if it were running all by itself on an actual host. This makes it easier to deploy the unique

environments that some applications require.

The obvious security concern lies in the isolation. What happens if a container has access to another containers

resources? Given that containers for rival companies may be running next to each other on the same machine in the cloud,

what are the risks of having a malicious container access or disrupt another?

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="10.1.3. Container Orchestration Systems"}

choices.B: Exploitation of a vulnerability in the kernel's namespace cloning mechanism
choices.C: Insufficient resource limits set by cgroups
choices.D: Misuse of the NET_ADMIN capability within a container

explanation: The correct answer, "Exploitation of a vulnerability in the kernel's namespace cloning mechanism," requires an understanding of how Linux namespaces are used to isolate containers and the potential risks if there are vulnerabilities in the kernel's implementation of these namespaces. This question encourages deep engagement with the content by requiring the test-taker to think critically about the potential weaknesses in container isolation mechanisms.

### 5.5.6. XML Injection {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__xml_injection}
XML stands for extensible markup language, and it is often used to transfer messages. XML can be an important part of a

web systems infrastructure and as such if unsanitized user inputs are allowed to generate XML the is used in the system

many things can go wrong. Using XML injection an attacker may be able to retrieve secret files or create admin accounts.

XML injection can be mitigated by input validation or possibly disabling the resolution of external entities in the

framework being used.

:::

### 5.5.7. LDAP Injection {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ldap_injection}
Finally, Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) is often used to store information about users. As such, it can be

found behind many web applications. LDAP also supports complex queries in a similar fashion to SQL. An unsantized user

input can lead to a LDAP query with unexpected results.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="5.5.8. Directory Traversal"}

choices.B: Input validation and sanitization
choices.C: Regular system updates
choices.D: Encryption of user data

context: ## 2.7. Asymmetric Encryption {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__asymmetric_encryption} An asymmetric encryption algorithm has actually already been demonstrated in the [Mathematical Foundation](#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__mathematical_foundation){#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml_xref-_mathematical_foundation .xref} section. Asymmetric encryption has a public key which can be published anywhere and used to encrypt messages that only the holder of the private key, which is not published, can unencrypt. For example if you want to receive encrypted emails you may make your [GNU Privacy Guard (GPG)](https://gnupg.org/){.link} public key available a [public key server](https://keyserver.ubuntu.com/){.link}. This would allow anyone to look up your public key, encrypt a message that only you can read, and send you the ciphertext. Asymmetric encryption gets around the difficulties of key exchange via an untrusted channel (like email). Unfortunately the cost of such a useful system is that asymmetric algorithms tend to be much slower that their symmetric counterparts. ::: ::: {.section .sect2 title="2.8. Stream Ciphers"}
topic: Evaluating the suitability of asymmetric encryption for different scenarios, considering factors such as security requirements, performance needs, and the infrastructure available for key management.
question: What scenario would most justify the use of asymmetric encryption despite its slower performance compared to symmetric encryption?

choices.A: Secure communication over a trusted network where speed is paramount.
choices.B: Real-time data encryption for high-speed transactions.
choices.C: Exchange of sensitive information over an untrusted public network.
choices.D: Local data encryption on a personal device for privacy.

explanation: Asymmetric encryption is particularly useful when secure key exchange is a challenge, such as communicating over an untrusted public network. Its ability to use a public key for encryption and a private key for decryption makes it ideal for scenarios where secure key exchange is difficult or impossible, outweighing the performance disadvantage.

## 6.3. Network Solutions {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__network_solutions}
Many products are available for handling network traffic. They are typically marketed as either stand-alone devices,

software to install on internal devices, or a subscription service that routes traffic through an external appliance. In

the age of cloud computing network security as a service is becoming increasingly popular.

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.1. Firewall"}


### 6.3.1. Firewall {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__firewall}
A firewall is a service/software/device that blocks unwanted traffic and permits wanted traffic. Typically a firewall is

a barrier between and private network and the Internet.

Software like [nftables](https://wiki.nftables.org/wiki-nftables/index.php/Main_Page){.link} can be used to build a

firewall on a Linux router for many interior clients. Interior clients may also run host-based firewalls such as

[Windows Defender

Firewall](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/security/threat-protection/windows-firewall/windows-firewall-with-advanced-security){.link}.

Finally hardware solutions for plug-in firewall devices are available from many vendors including Palo Alto and Cisco.

Any combination of these solutions may be used.

Firewalls typically employ rules regarding which packets can come in and how to handle them. For example a firewall may

have a rule to `ALLOW`{.literal} packets from exterior hosts connecting on port 22. This would allow SSH connections.

Likewise a firewall may have a rule to track internal to external connection requests and perform network address

translation (NAT). On an IPv4 network it is common to have a firewall also perform NAT.

Next-Gen Firewalls (NGFW) perform the same functions of a standard firewall, but also employ an integrated intrusion

prevention system (IPS) to mitigate threats. The firewall is a perfect place to perform these actions as it can easily

close of connections. NGFW often tout artificial intelligence threat monitoring and automatic threat intelligence

updating (typically updating attack signatures). A NGFW can also easily be built on a Linux device by making use of [an

IPS](https://www.snort.org/){.link} in conjunction with a netfilter firewall.

Network infrastructure may also make use of a special space *outside* of a firewall called the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ).

Servers that need to be directly connected to the Internet are often put in the DMZ so they don't have a deal with

restrictive firewall rules. These servers may be used to detect malicious activity, monitor incoming traffic, or to

handle basic requests such as serving static web pages.

The largest firewall in the world is the Chinese Great Firewall, started in 1998 as a way to prevent outside influence

in China. It is a system used to block IPs, hijack DNS queries, throttle traffic, and perform MitM decryption. The Great

Firewall is made of proxies and firewalls performing packet-inspection and content filtering. VPNs are often employed

within China to circumvent the great firewall and the great firewall is continually updated to attempt to detect and

shut down this traffic.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.2. Proxy"}

### 3.6.6. Command and Control (C2, C&C) {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__command_and_control_c2_cc}
Malware will reach out via its Command and Control channel for more instructions. At this point an attacker may interact

with the malware, giving it additional commands. C2 traffic is usually designed to blend in with existing traffic and

not draw attention.

:::

::: {.section .sect3 title="3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives"}


### 3.6.7. Exfiltration / Actions & Objectives {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__exfiltration_actions_objectives}
The final step involves getting data from the exploited systems or disabling/misusing the systems in another way. At

this point an attacker can use the C2 channel to pull sensitive information from the system, credit card information,

password hashes, etc. Its important to not that exfiltration of data may not be the only goal of the attack. An attacker

can also disable the system, commit fraud with the system, mine crypto currencies, etc. At this point the malicious

actor is in complete control of the exploited system.

:::

context: ### 6.3.2. Proxy {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__proxy} A proxy typically sits between the users and an external network. Proxies and receive and send requests on behalf of a user, allowing for full control over the traffic going out and coming back in. Proxies can be used for caching, access control, URL filtering, content scanning, and even packet inspection. Proxy solutions may be explicit or transparent and are offered by many companies including McAfee, Fortigate, Netsparker, and Palo Alto. A typical application of a proxy would be to filter explicit content on a school district network. Proxies can also be broken into *forward* and *reverse* configurations. A forward proxy passes requests from a private or internal network to the internet. Forward proxies can speed up local requests through caching and validate that the request should be performed. Forward proxies are interoperable with standard firewalls and network address translation (NAT). Reverse proxies take requests from an external source and pass it to an internal service. This helps prevent clients from having direct access to internal services. Reverse proxies can utilize caching and validate requests as well. A reverse proxy can also be configured to work with a firewall. Whereas it used to be common practice to place a server in a demilitarized zone (DMZ) outside of a firewall, it is now far more common to employ a reverse proxy to reach that server. ::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="6.3.3. Load Balancer"}

choices.C: Enhanced caching capabilities for frequent requests

context: ### 4.2.2. ICMP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__icmp} Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) is largely used to send messages between systems when IP doesn't work. For example, lets say we tried to connect to a host but our router doesn't know how to get there. Our router can send us an ICMP *Destination Unreachable* message to let us know that something is going wrong. Because ICMP messages work at the network layer, we will receive this message even if there is an issue with the internet layer. The most common use for ICMP is the `ping`{.literal} command. `ping`{.literal} sends an ICMP echo request to check to see if a host is up. By responding to the request with the data included in the request we can assume that the host is up and functioning. ICMP is also used in the `traceroute`{.literal} command. `traceroute`{.literal} incrementally increase the Time To Live (TTL) field of ICMP packets and watches for *TTL Exceeded* messages to determine what route packets are taking to get to a host. Example `traceroute`{.literal} output is shown below: ::: callout-list 1. *①* Notice these routers not responding to ICMP packets ::: Despite the usefulness of ICMP, ICMP packets from external sources are often ignored. Network engineers use ICMP to troubleshoot their own networks, but it would be a security issue to allow outside parties to do the same. As such, do not expect all external hosts to respond to pings. They may still be up, but you'll need to figure out [another way to detect them.](https://nmap.org/book/man-host-discovery.html){.link} :::: ::: {.section .sect3 title="4.2.3. NAT"}

choices.A: It increases the risk of DDoS attacks, necessitating the use of alternative diagnostic tools.
choices.B: It compromises network privacy by revealing internal IP addresses.

### 3.3.1. Worms, Viruses, and Trojans {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__worms_viruses_and_trojans}
Worms are self-propagating programs that spread without user interaction. Their code is typically stored within an

independent object, such as a hidden executable file. Worms often do not severely damage their host, as they are

concerned with rapid, exponential spreading.

::::: example

::: example-title

Stuxnet

:::

::: example-content

Stuxnet was a 2010 worm that specifically targeted Iranian nuclear facilities. The worm used an unprecedented four

zero-day attacks and was designed to spread via USB flash drives and Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs). In this way it

didn't just rely on networks to propagate. Ultimately Stuxnet's payload targeted the code used to program PLC devices

that control motors and make them spin too fast, destroying the centrifuges. Stuxnet also employed an impressive rootkit

to cover its tracks. Given the level of sophistication Stuxnet is believed to have been developed by the US and Israel.

:::

:::::

Viruses typically require user interaction, such as copying and infected file from one machine to another, and store

their code inside another file on a machine. An executable file may be infected by having the virus code added a

separate page that executes before the standard program code. Viruses can be quite damaging to the host as they may take

significant resources to spread locally. The term virus is also an unfortunately overloaded one. Due to it's popularity

it is often used by some lower-skill threat actors to refer to many different types of malware.

::::: example

::: example-title

Concept Virus

:::

::: example-content

The Concept virus was the first example of a Microsoft Word macro virus. The virus hid itself inside Microsoft Word

files and used Word's embedded macro language to perform its replication tasks. Viruses were later created for Excel and

other programs that had sufficiently sophisticated yet ultimately insecure internal scripting languages.

:::

:::::

A trojan is a form of malware that disguises itself as legitimate software. It does not have to rely on a software

exploit as much as it exploits users into installing, running, or giving extra privileges to the malicious code. Trojans

are the most popular kind of malware as they can be used as an attack vector for many other payloads. The name comes

from Greek mythology, where a Trojan horse was disguised as a gift and given to a besieged town. Within the large horse

were secret troops who came out in the middle of the night and opened the town gates.

::::: example

::: example-title

Emotet

:::

::: example-content

Emotet is a banking trojan from 2014 that spread through emails. It made use of malicious links or macro-enabled

documents to make the user download its code. Emotet has been one of the most costly and destructive pieces of malware

currently averaging about one million in incident remediation. It continues to be adapted to avoid detection and make

use of even more sophisticated malware.

:::

:::::

::::::::::::

### 4.2.1. IP {#_computer_systems_security_planning_for_success.xhtml__ip}
IP stands for internet protocol and it was devised to allow creating a network of networks. The network of networks that

uses it primarily is the Internet, although you could use IP in other scenarios as well. IP is largely concerned with

*routing* traffic across and to networks. The protocol was first detailed by the IEEE in 1974 and comes from the

Advanced Research Projects Agency Network (ARPANET) project, which created the first large, packet-switched network.

Most people are familiar with IP addresses, the unique number given to a host participating in an IP network. Currently

there are two main versions of the IP protocol, IPv4 and IPv6, and one of the major differences is in how many IP

addresses are available. IPv4 supports 32 bit addresses and IPv6 supports 128 bit addresses. To give an idea of how big

of a change that is, we have currently allocated all possible IPv4 addresses, but with IPv6 we could give an address to

every grain of sand on the beaches of earth and still not run out.

<aside class="sidebar titled" title="IPv6 Security Implications" epub:type="sidebar">

choices.C: Virtually unlimited address space, enabling unique identification and management of a vast number of devices

This feature enables each device to have a unique address, facilitating efficient communication, management, and security within IoT networks.
